node.title: U.S. Holocaust Museum Says China ‘May Be Committing Genocide’ Against Uyghurs
node.alt: Members of a Uyghur family prayed at the grave of a loved one at a cemetery in Xinjiang in 2016.
node.description: Its report found that the government’s attacks against the group of Muslims in Xinjiang had escalated and most likely included “forced sterilization, sexual violence, enslavement, torture, and forcible transfer.”
node.content: ["The U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum said in a report issued on Tuesday that China had escalated its crimes against the Muslim community of Uyghurs in the northwestern region of Xinjiang and that it was \u201cgravely concerned\u201d that the government \u201cmay be committing genocide.\u201d", "The report, \u201c\u2018To Make Us Slowly Disappear\u2019: The Chinese Government\u2019s Assault on the Uyghurs,\u201d builds on a March 2020 announcement made by the museum that there was \u201creasonable basis\u201d to believe that the Chinese government \u201chad perpetrated the crimes against humanity of persecution and of imprisonment\u201d against the Uyghurs.", "Based on compiled evidence, the report issued Tuesday found there was now \u201creasonable basis\u201d to believe that the crimes include \u201cforced sterilization, sexual violence, enslavement, torture, and forcible transfer.\u201d", "In a statement, Tom Bernstein, chair of the museum\u2019s committee on conscience, called on the Chinese government to stop the crimes against the Uyghurs and allow independent international monitors to investigate.", "\u201cThe Chinese government has done its best to keep information about crimes against the Uyghurs from seeing the light of day,\u201d he said. \u201cThe information that has come out so far, including documentation from courageous Uyghur activists, has been damning.\u201d", "In a statement, Naomi Kikoler, director of the museum\u2019s Simon-Skjodt Center for the Prevention of Genocide, said that the \u201cChinese government\u2019s assault on the Uyghur community\u201d described in the report was \u201calarming in scale and severity.\u201d", "\u201cThe damage inflicted upon Uyghur individuals, families, and their community has left deep physical and emotional scars,\u201d she said. \u201cThe trauma from these atrocities will harm generations of Uyghurs.\u201d", "The report calls on the Chinese government to \u201cimmediately halt the commission of mass atrocity crimes,\u201d and lists specific next steps such as ending forced sterilization and forced abortion. But the Chinese government, which has over the years denied such crimes, is unlikely to be fazed by the report or follow through with any demands made of it.", "The Embassy of the People\u2019s Republic of China in Washington did not immediately respond to a request for comment about the report on Tuesday. But the Chinese government had spoken against such claims as recently as Oct. 21, when more than 40 countries, including the United States, criticized China\u2019s repression of the Uyghurs at a United Nations meeting. China\u2019s U.N. ambassador, Zhang Jun, responded by saying that the countries had made \u201cgroundless accusations against China.\u201d", "\u201cNo matter how many times repeated, lies are still lies,\u201d the ambassador said. \u201cYou are using human rights as a pretext for political maneuvering to provoke confrontation. In fact, you are the troublemaker and biggest obstacle to international human rights cooperation.\u201d", "The museum in its report concedes that \u201cit would be na\u00efve to expect the Chinese government to change course so dramatically without a concerted international effort.\u201d", "\u201cHaving publicly declared that China is committing genocide and crimes against humanity, the United States and like-minded governments must be at the center of the effort to press China to end its atrocities against the Uyghurs,\u201d the report said.", "Ned Price, a spokesman for the State Department, shared the museum\u2019s report on Twitter on Tuesday, saying that it renewed \u201cour call for the People\u2019s Republic of China to end its crimes against Uyghurs and members of other ethnic and religious minority groups in Xinjiang.\u201d", "The Uyghurs have long expressed resentment for China\u2019s control of the Xinjiang region, saying they have been discriminated against, while one million or more people in internment camps have been detained for a number of acts, including religious practice and violating birth restrictions.", "In one example cited in the report, an Uyghur woman recalled being beaten and raped while she was detained in Xinjiang in March 2018. The woman detailed being raped by men who used iron bars and electric batons, and later being raped by three men together.", "\u201cI remember it very clearly,\u201d the report quotes her as saying. \u201cI can\u2019t cry and I can\u2019t die \u2026 my soul and heart are dead.\u201d", "The United States has previously spoken out against China\u2019s treatment of the Uyghurs. In the final full day of the Trump administration, then-Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said that China was carrying out genocide in a \u201csystematic attempt to destroy Uyghurs.\u201d", "Under the Biden administration, in an annual report on human rights practices released in March, the United States condemned the Chinese government for what Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said was \u201cgenocide against Uyghurs\u201d and crimes of \u201cimprisonment, torture, enforced sterilization, and persecution.\u201d", "In its announcement in March 2020, the museum accused the Chinese of conducting forced assimilation of the Uyghurs. While that did not fall under the definition of genocide under the Genocide Convention, the museum said at the time, \u201cRegardless of its legal classification, assimilation threatens the continued existence of Uyghurs\u2019 cultural and religious practices.\u201d"]
